text: hi how are you
i have a really great spatchcock chicken
recipe another one yes spatchcock
chicken potatoes onions and watercress
salad the cool thing about this recipe
is that it cooks with vegetables
underneath it on a broiler pan so you
put your veg in here and you put your
chicken on here and it all cooks at the
same time
in the oven start with three potatoes
and just cut them into rounds half inch
thick they can't be too thick otherwise
they won't cook in the time it takes to
cook the chicken which because it's
spatchcock is only 35 minutes i just
love the idea that you can cook a whole
roast chicken in 35 minutes we like that
right time saving so my potatoes are cut
i have a broiler pan isn't this a pretty
color lined with aluminum foil just
helps for cleanup you really don't have
to do it so drizzle your pan while your
foil with a little bit of oil only a
teaspoon and a half and then add your
potatoes and then just turn to coat them
just lightly in oil then a red onion
peel it and then cut it in half
lengthwise and then cut it crosswise
into half moons the onion should fall
apart into
half rings
so right onto the pan the onion could
just get sprinkled right on top of the
potatoes something kind of magical about
the flavor of potatoes and onions
roasted together don't you think you
season them with salt and pepper and
chicken fat
and it's ultra delish put your broiler
pan right on top of your vegetables what
happens is the fat drips through onto
the potatoes and the onions and helps
them cook and get all caramelized and
delicious i have my chicken on a cutting
board that can go right into the
dishwasher as i always do and it
sterilizes it remove the fat from inside
and then turn it over on its breast and
cut down along either side of the
backbone this is the neck it's the butt
so just cut from the neck to the butt
scissors is the easiest way to
accomplish this i think the one part
that might just be a little bit hard is
when you get to the thigh bone sometimes
it's a little hard to get around that
then i just like to turn it around to do
the other side it's easier because i'm
right handed cut alongside the backbone
and remove it the second side is always
just a little bit hard because it's a
little wobbly then it's out
don't forget to save your backbone save
a bunch of them put them in the freezer
every time you spatchcock a chicken
throw it in a resealable bag and then
eventually you can make stock open it up
just clean out anything that's on the
inside and then turn it over breastside
up and crush the breasts press the
breast until the breastbone breaks it
makes it extra flat the great thing
about spatchcocking is it's a really
really even and really fast cooking
method it cooks more evenly because it's
all flattened out
and then transfer it right to the top of
your broiler pan
i gotta wash my hands for a sec
drizzle with a tiny bit of olive oil
